<<<code>>>: public class FormattedStream extends FilterInputStream {
    private static final int AMP = '&';
    private static final int SEMICOLON = ';';
    private static final int AMP_ENCODED = 'a';
    private static final int AMP_ENCODED2 = 'm';
    private static final int AMP_ENCODED3 = 'p';

    public FormattedStream(InputStream src) {
        super(src);
    }

    @Override
    public int read() throws IOException {
        int b = super.read();
        if (b == AMP) {
            int next = super.read();
            if (next == AMP_ENCODED) {
                next = super.read();
                if (next == AMP_ENCODED2) {
                    next = super.read();
                    if (next == AMP_ENCODED3) {
                        next = super.read();
                        if (next == SEMICOLON) {
                            return AMP;
                        } else {
                            return next;
                        }
                    } else {
                        return next;
                    }
                } else {
                    return next;
                }
            } else {
                return next;
            }
        } else {
            return b;
        }
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: Instead of converting the entire stream into a String and back to a stream, you can override the read() method in the FormattedStream class to replace the & character on the fly. This way, you can avoid the unnecessary conversions and achieve a more elegant solution. The overridden read() method reads one byte at a time from the underlying InputStream and checks if it is the & character. If it is, it reads the next few bytes to check if it matches the encoded & character (&). If it does, it returns the original & character. Otherwise, it returns the next byte. This way, you can properly encode the & character without modifying other occurrences of & in the stream.
